title: Considering Students’ Perceptions of the Face Validity in Formative Quizzes: A Proposal for a Mixed-Methods Process for Analyzing Opinions on Content Value
Considering Students’ Perceptions of the Face Validity in Formative Quizzes: A Proposal for a Mixed-Methods Process for Analyzing Opinions on Content Value
text:
1.2 Motivation

Valid classroom assessment is hard
Student perceptions on evaluations are unclear
Student’s have opinions on the instructor, less on content
How can I bring students into the process of how I “grade” them

title: Considering Students’ Perceptions of the Face Validity in Formative Quizzes: A Proposal for a Mixed-Methods Process for Analyzing Opinions on Content Value
text:
1.3 Value of Student Buy-in

Students may see assessment as accountability at best, irrelevant at worst (Brown & Hirschfeld, 2008; Fletcher et al., 2012)
Trust is important so they can learn from assessment (Carless, 2009; Chu et al., 2014; Leighton & Bustos Gómez, 2018)
The right, little “moves” can help make that trust more tangible (Felten et al., 2023)

title: Considering Students’ Perceptions of the Face Validity in Formative Quizzes: A Proposal for a Mixed-Methods Process for Analyzing Opinions on Content Value
text:
2.1 Assessment at Regular Interval

I already had consistent weekly quizzes as a mainstay in my courses
Associated with good effects on retention (Haigh, 2007; Thomas et al., 2020)
When corrective feedback is fast, supports better self-correction (Marcell, 2008)
My existing structure was ripe for addition

title: Considering Students’ Perceptions of the Face Validity in Formative Quizzes: A Proposal for a Mixed-Methods Process for Analyzing Opinions on Content Value
text:
2.2 Embed in the Assessment

10-question multiple-choice quiz, open-note, relatively low stakes
Embed in 1 - 2 quant/qual questions to assess “accuracy” of quiz
Aim to capture an immediate “state”-like feeling, knee-jerk reaction (similar to Spielberger (2012))

title: Considering Students’ Perceptions of the Face Validity in Formative Quizzes: A Proposal for a Mixed-Methods Process for Analyzing Opinions on Content Value
text:
2.3 Format of the Question

Research on face validity from the student perspective is sparse at times
Does show it’s importance in maintaining relevance to the student (Hollis‐Sawyer & Sawyer, 2008; Sato & Ikeda, 2015)
Some examples:

“Rate how close this quiz was to what we learned in class last week (1 - 5)”
“Do you feel like this content was covered in class? (yes / no)”
“Explain whether you feel this was representative of what you know (open)”
“What other topic were you expecting to show up that didn’t (open)”

title: Considering Students’ Perceptions of the Face Validity in Formative Quizzes: A Proposal for a Mixed-Methods Process for Analyzing Opinions on Content Value
text:
2.4 Debrief and Analysis

If easily accessible through LMS, may display bar graphs on board for numerical questions
Look for common vocabulary in the open responses
Use the insights from the qualitative to follow-up on the quantitative

title: Considering Students’ Perceptions of the Face Validity in Formative Quizzes: A Proposal for a Mixed-Methods Process for Analyzing Opinions on Content Value
text:
3.1 Things to Avoid

Creating culture of arguing for points
Students aren’t SMEs, you don’t need to treat them like one!
Only using quant or qual - use both!
Trying to do too much!
